texts.definition: Players provided with abilities to affect how a game is played.
markups: <style="Definition">Players provided with abilities to affect how a game is played.</style>

Games provide players with a range of actions they can perform in order to try and reach the goals they or the game has set up. However, some games also provide players with abilities that affect the structure of the game itself. These <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> are implied to take on a responsibility for the gameplay experience of all players so these abilities are not supposed to be used for personal gains.

Multi-User Dungeons such as BatMUD, DragonMud, and Kingdoms let experienced players become wizards, players that can create new entities in the game worlds as well as teleport and otherwise affect other players in ways they themselves cannot. From this position players can then move onto becoming game masters. The commercial Massively Multiplayer Online Game Ultima Online also allows players to become a form of Entitled Players, forming a first group that other players can contact for advice and questions.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Apocalypse%20World">Apocalypse World</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Universalis">Universalis</link></style> allow all players possibilities to affect the structure of the game world that the game takes place in. While <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Apocalypse%20World">Apocalypse World</link></style> primarily does this before gameplay proper begins, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Universalis">Universalis</link></style> lets players do this continuously by using a limited resource.

Creating <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> consists mainly of selecting which <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> to provide to players in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. Typical examples include <style="Link"><link="coaches">Coaches</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> (other types of <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Judges">Judges</link></style> tend not be be viewed as players). Typical <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> that signify <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> include those that allow <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="player-kicking">Player Kicking</link></style> is another possibility.

As with providing any type of <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Ability</link></style>, those given to <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> can negatively affect <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. This makes the pattern most often used in <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> with both <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> and player <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>.

Since one of the most common abilities for <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> is to allow them to create <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, this pattern can easily disrupt <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> since it only requires one player to create inappropriate content for the consistency to break.

<style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> can often perform <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> in some way, even if it is only through the creation of <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>, and this makes the pattern a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Narration%20Patterns">Narration Pattern</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> are those provided with <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> related to changing how a game works, rather than changing the game state of a game. In doing so they have a <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Role</link></style> related to mediating or facilitating the game. This often allows for <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>, and through this provide players with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>. While this can give them an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> it is typically not a problem regarding <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> since the pattern is most often used in <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> that encourage player <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>. When using their abilities magnanimously, <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> can support the <style="Link"><link="social-adaptability">Social Adaptability</link></style> of a game.

While <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style>, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Entitled Players</style> can offload the <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style> that <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> otherwise would have to perform.
